Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Developing Iridium-based Alloys as Effective Catalysts for Direct Ethanol Fuel Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fuel cells enable the conversion of different chemicals directly into electrical energy, and are much more efficient than conventional combustion engines. Direct ethanol fuel cells (DEFC) use ethanol as a fuel source. However, a limitation in commercialization of DEFCs is a cheap, efficient catalyst to break apart ethanol. Iridium alloys (a combination of two or more materials) are promising catalysts as they possess high catalytic activity and are cheaper than platinum, the traditional fuel cell catalyst. Synthesizing and testing all possible alloys experimentally is not realistic. The aim of this project is therefore to develop atomic models of Iridium-based alloys in order to predict which alloys may be stable, good catalysts. Simulations using high-performance computers allow fast, economical prediction of potential alloys, which may then be tested in the laboratory. This work thus will speed up commercialization of new DEFC catalysts and will be conducted in collaboration with Professor Koretaka Yuge, a noted expert in modeling metal alloys, at Kyoto University, Japan.

Developing efficient catalysts for direct ethanol fuel cells (DEFCs) is of special importance in the catalysis and fuel cell communities. DEFCs have several advantages compared to other types of fuel cells mainly because of their feed, ethanol, which has high energy density, is safer than hydrogen and is less toxic than methanol (both hydrogen and methanol are fuel cell feeds). To find the best Ir-based alloys the PI will use a combination of density functional theory (DFT) and the cluster expansion (CE) method. By using these two techniques simultaneously, the limitation of DFT methods due to finite computation power will be resolved. This project will be conducted at Kyoto University under the mentorship of Professor Koretaka Yuge who has done tremendous research on combining the DFT and CE methods.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is funded jointly by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energy and the environment are some of the biggest issues our society is dealing with. The current main source of energy production, fossil fuels cause adverse issues including environmental and health problems. Furthermore, the fossil fuel resources could be depleted in the future. To mitigate these problems, one alternative way of energy production are fuel cells. A fuel cell is a device which converts the chemical energy of a fuel directly into electricity and as a result is much more efficient than conventional heat engines. Among different kinds of fuel cells, direct ethanol fuel cells (DEFCs) use ethanol as a fuel source, which is less toxic than methanol, less explosive and less dangerous than pure hydrogen. Both methanol and hydrogen are potential fuel cell feeds. Direct ethanol fuel cells however, are not commercialized due to a lack of an efficient catalyst. The most traditional catalyst in the fuel cell industry, platinum, is highly expensive and is not efficient in the reactions occurring in DEFCs. In our research we proposed to substitute platinum with Iridium alloys. Iridium is an active catalyst and is much cheaper than platinum.

Our research therefore focuses on modeling different iridium alloys which have shown to have superior catalytic activity compared to the pure metal. The method which we are using is density functional theory (DFT). DFT is a computational chemistry method and gives an electronic-level description of atoms and molecules. After finding out the best viable alloys, the results will be given to experimentalists to validate the DFT data. The drawback of DFT calculations however, is their computation limitation. To resolve this problem, the combination of DFT with statistical physics methods, such as cluster expansion, is one possible solution. The aim of this project therefore is to design efficient iridium based alloys by the combination of DFT and the cluster expansion method. We started with modeling different iridium-platinum alloys as platinum is the most popular fuel cell catalyst. We then extended our studies to other bimetallic iridium alloys such as iridium-palladium, iridium-chromium, iridium-nickel, and so forth.

Our results show that iridium-platinum alloys possess positive formation energy which implies the tendency of these alloys towards phase segregation. Furthermore, the most stable structures for iridium-platinum alloys were determined, and the most stable configuration corresponded to the iridium-platinum half-half composition. Having positive formation energy along with visible phase segregation demonstrate the fact that iridium-platinum alloys do not mix well at ground state conditions (0K). As a result, a systematic study on bimetallic iridium-platinum alloys is being performed in the present study and our results so far have shown that alloys such as iridium-platinum and iridium-palladium possess positive formation energy while alloys such as iridium-chromium and iridium-nickel have negative formation energies and are more stable at ground state conditions. Furthermore, the most stable structures for each of these alloys were determined. The effect of temperature on the alloys’ structures was also investigated and for iridium-platinum alloys for instance, as the temperature increases the phase segregation decreases, meaning that the iridium and platinum tend to mix better.

Being awarded NSF EAPSI fellowship and conducting research at Kyoto University, Japan, not only enabled me to learn a new technique (the cluster expansion method) for modelling innovative catalysts, but also created the great opportunity for the collaboration between Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) and Kyoto University. I had the great opportunity to learn cluster expansion method under supervision of Professor Yuge who is an expert in modeling metal alloys by means of cluster expansion method and also developed his own cluster expansion code, GCVC. Furthermore, with Professor Yuge’s permission, I brought GCVC code to WPI which enabled me to continue my research about cluster expansion method. I gave presentations about my research and GCVC code to my research group at WPI and disseminated the knowledge I learned during the summer. The publication of the current research is under preparation and we are expecting to have a publication(s) from the current collaboration.

I also had the great opportunity to meet Professor Yuge again at February 27, 2017 during The Minerals, Metals & Materials Society (TMS2017) conference. We both presented our research in poster format in the “Computational Thermodynamics and Kinetics” symposium and we discussed my current progress on my research along with its possible directions.

 I also encouraged my fellow graduate students to apply to NSF EAPSI program and I am invited to participate in the next “Fellowship and proposal Workshop” which is being held at WPI annually in August.

I presented my research as a talk in the “Spring 2017 Meeting of the American Physical Society (APS) New England Section” and “Spring 2017 Meeting of New England Catalysis Society”. In both meetings I introduced the NSF EAPSI fellowship to my fellow researchers and encouraged them to apply to this once in a lifetime opportunity.
